Posts.Content: Hello Ella. Â I agree with the posters above - it’s your news and how you decide to tell people is what’s right for you. Personally, I’m a very heart on your sleeve, all out there person so once I told my close family and friends about my diagnosis (I had pancreatic cancer), I put a detailed and upbeat post on Facebook simply because I have friends and family all over the place (I’m originally from New Zealand and now live in the U.K.) and it was just easier to have it out there and leave it up to people to respond how they wanted to rather than endlessly repeating myself. The support and love I got were incredible but it also weeded out people too which was good. I believe in demystifying cancer and not being afraid to confront illness or death so I’m more than happy to talk about it but that’s just me. I understand if people are uncomfortable or want things to remain private. The people who matter have not treated me any differently which is great and my work have been fantastic but we’re a small industry and very tight knit. I have had the odd look of doom from acquaintances but I just laugh and say, “I’m all right, I’m still breathing!” Don’t get me wrong, I have down days but I’m open about those too and my family and friends soon cheer me up. I guess I just feel I’ve been given a chance to really appreciate life in a way I probably didn’t before cancer so I try to really get the most out of things I do now. Mostly...
Posts.Title: How to tell friends?

Posts.Content: Yes, some people do react as if they can “catch” cancer like a cold. Weird.
